description.plain: Beck took the lo-fi sound of DIY indie rock to the Billboard charts in 1994 with his slacker anthem “Loser,” but his avant-pop palette extends well beyond the folk-rap beats and samples of that hit; encompassing everything from funk, soul, and psychedelia to wild experiments with feedback, toy instruments, and found sounds. Plus, his disjointed, surreal lyrics (which were often compared to Highway 61 Revisited-era Bob Dylan) made for an alt-pop sound that helped define the ‘90s and made Beck one of the most interesting musicians of his era.

body.plain: Beck took the lo-fi sound of DIY indie rock to the Billboard charts in 1994 with his slacker anthem “Loser,” but his avant-pop palette extends well beyond the folk-rap beats and samples of that hit; encompassing everything from funk, soul, and psychedelia to wild experiments with feedback, toy instruments, and found sounds. Plus, his disjointed, surreal lyrics (which were often compared to Highway 61 Revisited-era Bob Dylan) made for an alt-pop sound that helped define the ‘90s and made Beck one of the most interesting musicians of his era.

songs.title: Loser

description.plain:
The verses of Beck’s breakout hit seem to be mainly a stream of consciousness consisting of nonsense while announcing to the world he’s just a slacker. But some feel he juxtaposes imagery of poverty with pop culture imagery, characterized by glamour and excess. Beck, however, has said that the rap began merely as an improvised poem recorded in his kitchen as a filler track.

“Loser” was anything but. Originally recorded in 1991 as a “fluke that I’d done messing around at a guy’s house”, it was not released until 1993 as a limited pressing of 500 copies on the independent label Bong Load. It quickly became popular on college radio and some alternative stations, and Geffen Records took interest in him.

Geffen’s reissue of “Loser” became Beck’s breakout hit, reaching #10 on the US pop chart and  becoming a Gold-certified single. It also spent 5 weeks at #1 on the Modern Rock chart. Overseas it was a top 20 hit in several countries including hitting #1 in Norway.

It not only launched Beck’s career into the mainstream but remains one of his signature songs, with Rolling Stone naming it one of the greatest songs of all time in 2011.

songs.embed_content: Read “Loser” by Beck on Genius

songs.lyrics:
152 ContributorsLoser Lyrics[Verse 1]
In the time of chimpanzees, I was a monkey
Butane in my veins, and I'm out to cut the junkie
With the plastic eyeballs, spray paint the vegetables
Dog food stalls with the beefcake pantyhose
Kill the headlights and put it in neutral
Stock car flaming with the loser in the cruise control
Baby's in Reno with the vitamin D
Got a couple of couches, sleep on the loveseat
Someone came, saying I'm insane to complain
About a shotgun wedding and a stain on my shirt
Don't believe everything that you breathe
You get a parking violation and a maggot on your sleeve
So shave your face with some mace in the dark
Saving all your food stamps and burning down the trailer park
Yo, cut it

[Chorus]
Soy un perdedor
I'm a loser, baby, so why don't you kill me?
(Double barrel buckshot)

The forces of evil in a bozo nightmare
Ban all the music with the phony gas chamber
'Cause one's got a weasel, and the other's got a flag
One's on the pole, shove the other in a bag
With the rerun shows and the cocaine nose job
The daytime crap of the folksinger slob
He hung himself with a guitar string
A slab of turkey neck, and it's hanging from a pigeon wing
You can't write if you can't relate
Trade the cash for the beat, for the body, for the heat
And my time is a piece of wax falling on a termite
Who's choking on the splinters

I'm a loser, baby, so why don't you kill me?

[Bridge]
(Yo, bring it on down)

(em llik uoy t'nod yhw os

Rodedrep nu yoS)

I'm a driver, I'm a winner
Things are gonna change, I can feel it

(I can't believe you)

(Ahh)

songs.title: Dreams

description.plain:
With a massive fusion of funk, dream pop, grunge rock, and electronica, “Dreams” is the explosive lead single from Beck’s tenth studio album, following the GRAMMY-winning success of 2014’s Morning Phase. Sonically, the song is the “opposite” of Morning Phase, Beck explained.

It started out as a heavy garage rock thing and became much more of a dance — some kind of hybrid.

A preview of the instrumental was posted on Beck’s Instagram on June 12, 2015. A second trailer was posted on Facebook on June 13. The third and final trailer was posted June 14.

The full track premiered through iHeartRadio on June 15, 2015. The same day, the song was also uploaded on VEVO.

songs.embed_content: Read “Dreams” by Beck on Genius

songs.title: Sexx Laws

description.plain: The first single from Midnite Vultures, “Sexx Laws” is a triumphant anthem of defiance against societal preconceptions of what men and women are expected to be.

songs.embed_content: Read “Sexx Laws” by Beck on Genius

body.plain: The first single from Midnite Vultures, “Sexx Laws” is a triumphant anthem of defiance against societal preconceptions of what men and women are expected to be.

songs.lyrics:
